description: From Latin scaber (“scabrous, rough; scabby, mangy, itchy”) (from scabō (“to scratch, scrape, abrade”), from Proto-Indo-European *skabʰ- (“to scratch”)) + English -ous; compare French scabreux, Late Latin scabrōsus.

adjectives.description: scabrous (comparative more scabrous, superlative most scabrous)

entries.meaning: Covered with scales or scabs; hence, very coarse or rough.
examples: Synonyms: scabby, scaly, scurfy; see also Thesaurus:scabby, Thesaurus:rough
After the incident with the gasoline, Noel’s burnt arm remained scabrous, and was susceptible to infections.
Synonyms: repulsive, vile; see also Thesaurus:unpleasant
The novel was a flagrantly scabrous bodice-ripper, and Rachael was ashamed to read it in public.

entries.meaning: (figurative) Of music, writing, etc.: lacking refinement; unmelodious, unmusical.
examples: Synonyms: harsh, rough; see also Thesaurus:cacophonous

entries.meaning: (figurative, chiefly US) Covered with a crust of dirt or grime.
